I pointed out that I knew where the section was, but I could not find a specific product, so I needed a staff member to assist in finding the product. This was huffed at and the staff member then asked another staff member to go with me to the chilled section. I had expected that the staff member would search for the product using some device, but no they walked to the chilled section and just looked at shelves, as I had already done. I asked the staff member is they could not search using a device and was told no as the online info codes were different. I have since purchased the product from Tesco! Where the store member searched for the product using a device!Asda your store standards have seriously dropped. Products being unavailable that were previously available. Less staff to support in store.I planned to send this directly to the store manager as feedback. But as you’ve removed that online option I have had to resort to a public statement. Well done on failing on all fronts Asda!

title: Asda supports this scam!
body: I am not surprised Asda has so many negative reviews.I recently found that an amount of £[ANONYMIZED] was being extracted from my bank account on a [DATE] basis by a firm called Complete Savings.  It seems I somehow signed up for [DATE] trial, of which I had no knowledge.  I managed to get reimbursed by this company only to find that by putting in an order with Asda [DATE] I had agreed to pay this [DATE] amount when the trial ended.I then wrote to the head of Asda. It was very difficult to extract the name of the top person, who I found is a Lord Stuart Rose.  I wrote to him on [DATE] and never got a reply.  Somehow I didn't expect one.I would urge customers to scrutinise their bank statements very carefully on a regular basis as some people make a lot of small purchases and sums like this are easy to miss.  Also, if you don't get paper statements, like we are encouraged, the amounts will be even easier to miss.Shame on Asda for signing up to this scam but judging by some of the reviews I have been reading, I am not surprised.  There are other supermarkets out there and like me, I suggest you avoid, avoid, avoid Asda from now on..

They did this and then informed me the balance was showing as [ANONYMIZED]. I said again this was incorrect. The teller tried for a [ANONYMIZED] time to call the manager but because he was not wearing his headset the call was again ignored. By this time the queue was beginning to get longer and I was getting more upset, so much so that I began to suffer a panic attack. I got my bank card out and said I would pay that way instead. The teller said I shouldn't have to when there was credit on my shopping card. She called for the manager again but he did not respond. The teller infront suggested trying the card [ANONYMIZED] more time and low and behold the screen showed a credit balance of [ANONYMIZED]. I paid for my shopping and apologised to the customer behind me for taking so long to get sorted. As I left the store shaking I walked past the manager who was laughing with a colleague and still not wearing the headset. If I had not been in such a state I would have said something but I couldn't. Due to this incident I had to take a betablocker to ease the panic attack and stop the shaking to enable me to drive home. I have not had to do this for [DATE] and I am very angry that I had to take a tablet [DATE] because of the anxiety caused by something that was not my fault. This is not the [ANONYMIZED] incident using my shopping card but it is definitely the worst. I would appreciate it if you could get your tills sorted out so I do not have to go through this embarrassment again.

title: [PERSON] ~ Shockingly Abysmal Home Delivery Service & Customer Service
body: Asda's home delivery service is not even worthy of [ANONYMIZED] star. I had been ordering Asda home deliveries since [DATE], and my previous experience [DATE] is certainly going to be my final experience with them. Before I chose Asda, I used to order shopping from Tesco, which I never had any issues with. However, due to the cost of living skyrocketing in [DATE], I opted to try shopping with Asda as I found their products significantly cheaper. Big mistake!Their product availability is abysmal ~ [ANONYMIZED] occasion in [DATE] where they actually had all of the items in my shopping with [ANONYMIZED] substitutes. Not only that, but their constant substitutions were poor. [ANONYMIZED] time, I ordered an aubergine, they sent me a cucumber instead… on another occasion I ordered a grout pen and they sent me a super glue pen… both completely irrelevant/significant items! Every time I ordered a delivery, I was always emailed [DATE] after the order asking to give feedback. I constantly responded to them and stated that their product availability was awful but clearly was a waste of time because nothing changed. They don't listen to their customers. Their payments for home deliveries are completely backwards. They take money out [DATE] before the order arrives, and then if products are unavailable and/or the substitutes are no good, then waiting for a refund took somewhere between [DATE]… basically they are quick to take the money out but when you require the money back? Different story entirely.When something goes wrong and you contact Asda, the level of service is mostly atrocious. It is a common pattern that they are unapologetic, unwilling to help and they do not resolve issues unless you ring them several times and chase them up.[DATE], I was due a home delivery and the delivery driver rung me during my delivery slot to say my delivery was cancelled due to their van breaking down, which was frustrating however I get these things happen sometimes. The driver was very unapologetic and blasé about the whole ordeal, he asked if I could come out and collect it ~ I don't drive plus I live a [ANONYMIZED] drive away; I explained this to him. He also asked if I knew of anybody else that could collect it, at this time I explained to him that if I was a driver then I wouldn't even be ordering a home delivery service and I wouldn't be paying extra for a delivery fee… He also told me that somebody would be in touch with me the following day to reschedule the delivery. Surprise surprise - nobody contacts me. So I ring Asda, to which they tell me that I in fact have to reschedule the delivery. So I arranged for [DATE], I had to pay yet another delivery charge in which I was told I would have it refunded as I had to pay a higher delivery fee, of no fault of my own! So my shopping arrives, I then asked the delivery driver if he knew how long it would be before I would receive a refund for the rescheduled delivery fee. He very abruptly told me to ring customer service and that he couldn't help me. Completely unnecessary and uncalled for. As I was packing away my shopping, I noticed that [ANONYMIZED] of my fridge items was [DATE] out of date and as the delivery driver had already gone at this point, I once again rung Asda. I explained the situation and they apologised, though their apology came off very disingenuous, sadly like a lot of their customer service advisors. I feel like they aren't actually sorry that I'm having an issue, I feel like they're only saying sorry because it's their job to say it.There's been other poor delivery experiences, where they have turned up much earlier than the time allocated on multiple occasions. They have delivered crates where products have carelessly packed at the store, and so have been damaged or spilled in the process. In those instances I've had to spend more time cleaning up than actually packing the damn items away. Some of the drivers genuinely stink. There was [ANONYMIZED] occasion where I didn't want a substitute, was told that I would have it refunded, however never received an email or any confirmation so had to call up Asda and chase up.Final straw was [DATE] I ordered a home delivery and it never turned up. I rung Asda and explained the situation. I was told I would receive an email [ANONYMIZED] later from the credit team. Still no response [ANONYMIZED], I ring Asda again. Was told exactly the same thing as the [ANONYMIZED] person. [ANONYMIZED] later I finally receive an email to say sorry if I haven't got the order but afraid they can't process my refund as my order was marked "correctly delivered to me" by [PERSON]. I rung Asda for a [ANONYMIZED] time and they finally agreed to refund me the full amount. The sheer audacity of them trying to take [ANONYMIZED] from me is SHAMEFUL. If you want an easy and non headache-inducing shop, then avoid Asda like the plague.

title: Rude ‘manager’
body: I am writing to express my deep dissatisfaction with the service I received at your [PERSON] fuel station on [ANONYMIZED]. The incident not only caused significant delay and inconvenience whilst I was already running short of time, but also resulted in undue embarrassment due to the behavior of [ANONYMIZED] of your staff members.Upon arriving at the fuel station, I followed the usual procedure to fill my vehicle. However, before leaving I was abruptly and rather rudely interrupted by a staff member, [PERSON], who accused me of not paying the correct about of money. Despite my attempts to explain and clarify the situation, the staff member continued to argue in an extremely rude and dismissive manner.I paid £[ANONYMIZED] for fuel at the checkout. However, the ‘manager’ [PERSON] incorrectly claimed that I had only paid £[ANONYMIZED] and insisted that I needed to pay an additional amount. Despite my assurance that I had paid the correct amount, the staff member continued to argue with me in an aggressive and confrontational manner. To resolve the dispute, I checked my bank statement and provided evidence that I had indeed paid £[ANONYMIZED] than acknowledging her mistake, she falsely accused me of paying at the wrong till because she claimed I had stated the wrong till number. This accusation was completely unfounded and highly unprofessional. When I was finally refunded £[ANONYMIZED] to rectify the payment error, the cashier was unable to provide me with a refund receipt, adding to my frustration and inconvenience.The entire episode caused an unnecessary delay, leaving other customers visibly frustrated and creating an uncomfortable scene. I felt embarrassed and humiliated by the unwarranted attention and the accusatory tone used by your employee. To exacerbate the situation, it was eventually confirmed that I had been correct all along, and the staff member’s actions were unjustified.Moreover, [PERSON]’s extremely accusatory tone and refusal to apologise for the confusion was very unwelcoming and loud in front of other customers, wrongly insisted that I had given an incorrect till number, which was not the case. I clearly stated the correct till number multiple times, yet the employee continued to argue with me in a highly unprofessional manner.When I enquired about the complaint procedure, [PERSON] was highly reluctant to give me any information. When I insisted, it was revealed that she was in fact not the manager of the store but the supervisor and had misled me. This dishonesty further compounded the poor experience and reflects a serious issue in staff integrity and customer service at your store.I expect a certain level of professionalism and courtesy from Asda and Esso staff, and this incident fell far short of those expectations. Such behavior is unacceptable and does not reflect well on your company’s reputation for customer service.I request a formal apology from the staff member involved and assurances that such an incident will not occur again. Additionally, I would appreciate an explanation of the steps Asda and Esso will take to prevent similar occurrences in the future.

body: Don't get me wrong with this rating, the local Asda store staff are just 'fine'; interacting with one is like pulling a robot from its predetermined path - there'll be an acknowledgment that something has happened, then it'll just continue on it's original route // I don't blame the staff for this, I blame the current greed culture that breaks human beings to the point they turn into this just to get through [DATE]... // The meat if this rating is the online store and its [DATE] levels of manipulation - from forcing sponsored products beyond what Amazon does, even to the point of having them in your favourites list, to raising basic prices by [ANONYMIZED], then claiming '[PERSON]' status, so you 'get' £[ANONYMIZED] back when you buy said item; even going so far as to advertise the original price as 'massive savings' when the 'deal' is over - it's absolutely disgusting behaviour, but people /are/ raging imbeciles I guess... // Oh, they'll take your money out a day in advance for deliveries, but you'll have to wait the best part of [DATE] for a refund of any kind! // The only redeeming factor is that I've never had a bad driver - 10 stars for the drivers alone, as they're pulling all this weight as well as misguided anger from people who blame the messenger rather than the source. All my drivers are fantastic and I'll gladly go out of my way to help them where I can; the sites/stores need some serious work and the money better shared amongst the actual workers rather than the people at the top who have no idea what it's like to use a store like Asda..

title: Great shopping experience
body: [ANONYMIZED] time I've done an online shop with Asda, and I must admit, I saw so many bad reviews that I was a bit dubious. I don't know anyone in my area who uses Asda either, so nobody to get an opinion from. I really wanted the Jack Daniels that was on offer, and sods law, it was the only item that was subbed, apart from a couple of packets of rice! I received an email beforehand too, informing me of the subbed items, so I had time to decide whether I would keep them or not. I couldn't amend my order by then, so I would have had to return them via the driver. I decided to keep the 'subs' anyway, and I received the price difference as a refund into my bank account [DATE]. I was really pleased with everything, from ordering, (except I couldn't find out how to request no substitutes), to delivery. I bought lots of items that my local store doesn't sell, so have lots of new products and flavours to try. I didn't order any fresh/chilled  items, except fruit and breakfast shakes, as I don't always trust people to pick up long dated products. The dates on the items I did buy were really good. I also ended up having to contact customer services to query something, as the chat option on the app couldn't really help. I got through straightaway, and my question answered. The driver came [ANONYMIZED] early, luckily I was in. He was really helpful and friendly. The delivery prices are cheap too, especially if you choose [ANONYMIZED], or [ANONYMIZED] as I did. So, maybe I was just really lucky, but I cannot fault the experience I had with Asda. [ANONYMIZED] thing I noticed though, there was no date on when special offers were due to end, I couldn't see anything anyway. That would be a really useful feature to include.

On [ANONYMIZED] very recent visits to my local store in [LOCATION] I've been snapped at by [ANONYMIZED] different staff members: on the [ANONYMIZED] occasion the implication seemed to be that I must be an idiot because I'm not trained on their machines (funny, that); the [ANONYMIZED] time, in response to a very simple query, the young woman wafted an arm in my general direction without looking me anywhere near the face, barked something unintelligible and sauntered away, for all the world as if she owned the place, to the other end of the area, slowing down anyone with a trolley who happened to be trying to leave at that moment. I doubt this person has received (or absorbed) even the most basic training in customer service - but I don't think I was singled out, and I don't believe the level of arrogance and disdain she showed towards me was a [ANONYMIZED]-off either. In my view, she needs help, and she needs it fast. I avoid Asda as much as possible now - why should I put up with being overcharged, plus having to do my own checkout, and being insulted while I'm at it? [ANONYMIZED] good point though -- mysteriously, since I've now lost count of the times I've bought 'fresh' veg only for it to rot within a day or [ANONYMIZED], even in the fridge, and even though one of the 'fresh' eggs I bought [DATE] revealed, on being cracked open, a sight that made me want to throw up...Asda's avocados are actually pretty good. title: Asda Slough Pharmacy
body: On the Asda Slough website it states that the pharmacy is open as follows Mon-Fri: [ANONYMIZED] PM1:00 PM - 4:30 PM5:00 PM - 9:00 PMHowever, on several occasions (varying times)  I've arrived and the pharmacy has been closed with the shutters down and a sign saying the pharmacist is on a break. I get that they need a break but it's always during times when they are meant to be open. [DATE] for example I arrived at 1:46pm and it was closed with a sign saying the pharmacist was on a break from [ANONYMIZED] to [ANONYMIZED]. There was a lady (tired after her shift that started at [ANONYMIZED]) who'd been there waiting since [DATE].  It was meant to be open from [ANONYMIZED] according to the website.  She was unable to go home and come back again. When she was finally served she was told she'd have to wait [ANONYMIZED]. Another customer turned up having been told to come after [ANONYMIZED] for an over-the-counter item only to find it closed. The pharmacist arrived back after [DATE]. The other staff had no update on where he was and made no attempt to acknowledge anyone waiting. I feel they were embarrassed and not wanting confrontations. When it was my turn to be served I was told prescriptions take [ANONYMIZED]. It's hard enough getting a GP appointment, but when you finally do there's more hassle trying to get meds. Again, I'm all for staff getting breaks. But you need to set people's expectations. Many people  rush out in their limited lunch hour at work to get their prescriptions.  It makes sense that the staff lunch breaks not be around a typical lunch hour. If you are just going in for the 'over-the-counter' items you cannot get them either if the pharmacist is not there. This really needs to be addressed. No wonder customers get  frustrated - and then the poor counter staff are left to deal with them. FYI - I've come away without my medication [DATE] and have to make a special trip back there later. Even then it may not be ready as they are stating [ANONYMIZED] for prescriptions. This is even when the script has been sent across electronically [DATE].It's probably better to go the pharmacy near [ANONYMIZED] or if you are mobile use the one on Burnham High Street. It's better equipped to serve customers. [[Edit - so after being told to come back after [ANONYMIZED] - I went back at 6:20pm and it was CLOSED AGAIN with a sign saying open again at 6:45pm. This is disgraceful customer service. You need to make a change to the open times on the website so that people don't have (multiple) wasted journeys]]

title: Disability discrimination - value ranges not available to order online.
body: I am a disabled customer on a low income and order  my groceries online as I am unable to get to supermarkets, and have been really disappointed lately to not be able to buy certain value range "Just essentials" items. I thought this was just due to general inflation and was affecting everybody equally, however I was disgusted to learn that these items, in particular the Just Essentials coffee, baked beans and soya milk have not disappeared for those able to shop in person, but have selectively been made unavailable to those shopping from home, which includes a large proportion of disabled and elderly customers. ASDA have clearly made a callous and discriminatory calculation that those who can only order online often have no option but to buy the more expensive brand products, penalising their most vulnerable customers who are often on low incomes and really rely on value ranges, yet able bodied customers can walk in and buy them.

title: Shocking delivery/customer service
body: I have always ordered my shopping from Asda- I’m autistic and the whole experience of shopping is far too overwhelming. Assuming he had left my shopping at the bottom of the stairs, I went down to find that he had driven away with my shopping. I got an email to say the order had been cancelled. I rang the driver to ask and he cut me off then let it ring out then cut me off. I rang customer services who told me the driver cancelled due to no one being at home (even though he spoke to me and I buzzed him in TWICE). Customer service “help line” kept telling me they cannot help me and offered me a £[ANONYMIZED] voucher… I ordered £[ANONYMIZED] worth of shopping so what good is a £[ANONYMIZED] voucher?! Absolutely shocking service, delivery is suppose to make the whole experience easier and a lot less stressful!!! On top of that, they never deliver in bags so you have to unpack each individual item one by one… obviously some drivers cannot be bothered to actually deliver to your front door so you will have to carry each item up the stairs to your front door! However, iceland deliver in bags and I’ve never had any problems with them :)

title: Shopping cards leave customers vulnerable
body: I recently purchased some clothing using my mobile wallet. I needed to return these items and was told i needed to have my physical card or accept a shopping card.  I accepted the shopping card.  I used this on [ANONYMIZED] occasion afterwards for less than the value of the card.  On my [ANONYMIZED] visit I dropped my card somewhere in store and despite searching was unable to find it (I had only been in the clothing section when I realised it had slipped from my hand.  It hasn't been handed in to customer services and I asked if it was possible to cancel the card in case someone had picked it up and tried to use it/ or it wasn't found.  I was told this wasn't possible, despite me having the receipt for it and there was nothing they or I could do if I hadn't registered the card when I received it.  I had been given no information regarding registering the card when I was given it.  I feel that the lack of information given regarding the need to register the card and the inability to stop acard should it be lost or stolen leaves customers very vulnerable to being out of pocket. Please ensure staff inform customers about the need to register their card and enable cards to be stopped if they are lost or stolen [ANONYMIZED]

body: Ordered £[ANONYMIZED] worth of food to arrive early on [DATE] [ANONYMIZED]. No one arrived. [ANONYMIZED] time I called the advisor assured me that they were just running late. Like the majority of people, if you call and explain to me that you’re running late or just won’t make it I will completely understand. Things happen. But no one called or text.During a cost of living crisis to take people’s money for food that they will never receive is absolutely criminal. I am incredibly fortunate that I could afford to go and buy our food elsewhere, but for many people in the country that’s not the case. Does Asda expect people to starve whilst they battle to get their money back without a formal complaints system? I wouldn’t be so angry if this was a clothes order or something material. title: What on earth has happened to Asda
body: What on earth has happened to Asda? I know now why I no longer shop with them. Purchased a [PERSON] cleaner and [DATE] after [DATE] light usage the belt went on it. I duly phoned the technical department and after taking it apart I sent photos, as requested, of the hoover and the snapped belt. So one would assume they would send a replacement belt out for it. Oh no. They don't stock indeed sell replacement belts? I had checked on the Internet beforehand but couldn't find any recommended belts just dodgy belts from [ANONYMIZED] parties with mixed reviews.  So I asked what shall I do? Oh take it back to the shop for a replacement or refund? I said this wasn't satisfactory because what happens if I get a replacement and this problem keeps happening and after the warranty period the product is useless because I can't buy any suitable replacement belts. No answer other than they don't sell non perishable items such as belts? I stated so the belt shouldn't break,the answer was that's right. So I said what happens when belt does break. Take back to store if in warranty and you have a receipt. If outside warranty? No answer.  Shocking absolutely shocking.  So I asked what happens to new hoovers like this which are returned? Broken down for spare parts. What about older models which have been well used? Landfill. I can't believe that someone who sells hoovers don't even stock and sell replacement belts they simply fill landfill sites across the [LOCATION] with returned products instead. A simple bely. I was even asked to check instore for a belt? I said what an invisible one? If the Technical team don't have them then the store won't.  I got the impression the person simply wasn't interested.  In all fairness she didn't make the rules etc . So the moral of this is to check and research well before you buy from Asda. How easy replacement parts for products are to obtain or indeed do they even exist.  I personally can't afford to buy belt after belt after belt if those available have mixed reviews on quality and durability of such belts. Simply buy from elsewhere and avoid the hassle

body: I recently visited ASDA Stonecot and unfortunately, I had an incredibly disappointing experience due to the extremely poor customer service provided by the GSM Vania. Unfortunately, [LOCATION]’s demeanor fell far short of these expectations.Moreover, [PERSON]’s lack of knowledge about the store’s policies procedures and overall products was evident. She seemed unaware of the basic protocols for handling customer complaints and seemed uninterested in escalating the matter or involving other colleague members who might have been better equipped to assist. This lack of competence and willingness to help left me feeling disregarded and unheard.What disappointed me the most was [LOCATION]’s inability to empathize with my situation. Customer service should always prioritize understanding and resolving customer issues promptly. However, [LOCATION] seemed more concerned with maintaining her authority than addressing my concerns. This level of indifference is unacceptable and reflects poorly on ASDA Stonecot as a whole.I sincerely hope that ASDA Head Office takes this feedback seriously and addresses the issue at hand. Customer service is a crucial aspect of any business, and the behavior exhibited by [LOCATION] was far from satisfactory. I urge the senior management team at asda head office to provide additional training to their managers, particularly in the area of customer relations, to ensure that future customers do not encounter the same disappointing experience.In conclusion, my visit to [PERSON] was marred by the extremely poor customer service displayed by the [PERSON] manager, [LOCATION]. Her dismissive attitude, lack of professionalism, and overall indifference towards my concerns were deeply unsatisfactory. I hope that Asda Head Office takes appropriate measures to rectify this issue and provides better training and support to their managers to improve the overall customer experience.

I’m too embarrassed to go back into Asda now as I fear this will happen again. I just hope Asda see this and up their service game for elderly and disabled staff.

title: My formal letter of complaint
body: Here is a letter of complaint to Asda. They don't have an address for you to send a letter of complaint, so hopefully they as well as  everyone else gets to see it here.Dear Asda Customer Service,I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction with a recent grocery delivery order. On [DATE], I ordered groceries for delivery and only received [ANONYMIZED] of the order upon arrival. Luckily, a neighbor who also had an Asda delivery that night confirmed the driver had some unscheduled items in his van, which turned out to be [ANONYMIZED] of my order.  If I hadn't spoken to this neighbor or the driver, I wouldn't have received any groceries at all.I explained to the driver that this was only part of my order, and he assured me he would report the missing items upon returning to the store. [ANONYMIZED], I received a refund email from customer service with a partial refund list. However, there were still items missing from this list.Unfortunately, the online refund request system only allowed me to submit [ANONYMIZED] request at a time, with a maximum of [ANONYMIZED] requests. On top of this inconvenience and frustration, the online refund request system was also time-consuming. I also have to wait [DATE] before receiving my refund. This experience significantly disrupted my plans and ability to complete my work on schedule, forcing me to go out and buy the missing groceries, which cost me additional money as well as valuable work time. This left me feeling frustrated and put me under undue pressure.In a time when many families struggle to make ends meet, I find this level of service completely unacceptable and very concerning, especially considering the additional wait for the refund to be able to purchase the missing groceries.I have been a loyal Asda customer for [DATE], and I hope to continue using your services in the future. However, a more efficient and reliable delivery experience is crucial for me, and I am seriously considering taking my business elsewhere along with all the other services I currently use with Asda.I would very much appreciate it if you could investigate this matter thoroughly and offer an explanation to this fiasco, as well as a solution that demonstrates your commitment to customer satisfaction by offering a small gesture of goodwill.For your reference, I have included my order details below:Order number: ............................Sincerely,Miss .............................If any from Asda cares and would like to look into this, I would be happy to provide you with more details.

title: A bad experience for my disabled daughter
body: My disabled daughter and all my family have always shopped at Asda either instore or if she can not get out then she shops online. [DATE] sometime she had to do an online order as she would do if she was having [DATE]. When her shopping arrived she asked the driver if he could possibly help her take her shopping up [ANONYMIZED] flight of stairs as she was on her own that day. He was very rude to her and said no we don't carry your shopping we are not insured and if I hurt myself will you pay me my sick pay? He was very loud so she asked him to stop shouting at her and to just leave. She had to wait till her neighbour came home to help her. I told her to complain when it happened but she did not want to get the driver into trouble. We have continued to shop at Asda as we have always said it is good value for money and love shopping there as the staff are very friendly. Since the incident my daughter has placed [ANONYMIZED] online orders which have both been cancelled at the very last minute! We could not understand it but a friend of mine has now told me that she thinks my daughter has been blacklisted because of the incident with the delivery driver! I am appalled that my daughter has not had any feedback from Asda or been given an opportunity to defend herself against the word of the driver. It would have been better customer service if someone could have at least told her why she was not being allowed to do any online orders. I do understand that delivery drivers are not supposed to help the customers if they have to carry the shopping up stairs but she has had some lovely drivers who have offered to help her when they can see she is struggling to carry it up herself, how do the poor elderly people who have got stairs get their shopping delivered? I am so disappointed at my daughters treatment after all our loyal [DATE] of shopping at Asda but  will now take our custom elsewhere where hopefully there is a bit more empathy for disabled customers, I just wish my daughter had complained at the time of the incident so her voice could have been heard, but instead a very nasty and rude delivery driver who was shouting at my daughter for asking for help has had my daughter blacklisted. I will let my friends and family know the situation and can assure you that they too will take their custom elsewhere. This is the [ANONYMIZED] complaint I have sent  regarding this incident and I have not received any response which does surprise me as I always assumed that as like other big supermarkets customers would always get a response about a complaint but obviously I was wrong about Asda. Your shop floor staff  are lovely and always very helpful it's just a shame that the actions of [ANONYMIZED] driver has now caused us to shop elsewhere. I'm afraid I can not remember the date of the incident that has caused all this as it was [DATE] sometime and we have only just realised that my daughter has been blacklisted as no one bothered to actually let my daughter know. The Date of experience given will be the [ANONYMIZED] online order placed and again cancelled without warning and without a reason being given.

title: Wow misled
body: Wow misled, I thinkAmazing. title: Controlling and [ANONYMIZED]
body: Unfortunately I am once again having to contact you after an unacceptable exchange with the same deputy store manager whom I referred to in this email chain from [DATE]. This happened on [DATE] at [ANONYMIZED]. It started when I was at the self service checkout scanning my items. I was scanning them individually as I get cashback from my bank if I make a certain number of transactions within [DATE], and before long I had [ANONYMIZED] ASDA employees hovering right behind me, watching while I scan the items. I continued to scan them, and then one of the [ANONYMIZED] staff members hovering behind me then asked why I was scanning them individually. I explained that it was because I get cashback from my bank for doing it this way. The staff member then seemed OK with this response and then left. [ANONYMIZED] another staff member asked what I was doing, so I explained it all over again to him. He said that the till was not a cash point. I replied to him stating that I wasn't getting cashback from the self service machine. I gave this staff member a demonstration so he could see how I was scanning and paying for the items. He seemed to understand and then left once he had noticed that I was not actually using the self service till as a "cash [ANONYMIZED].I then finished up scanning my items and proceeded to leave the store, but the biggest surprise was yet to follow. The store manager, or deputy manager whom I'd spoken to about sorting out the queue management at [DATE] [DATE] accosted me on the way out this time. He aggressively demanded to know what I had been doing and why I was doing it, so I explained it all over again to him for the [ANONYMIZED] time. He was very rude and called me "odd" & a "wrong un" for scanning my items the way I did. He also instructed me to do my shopping on a [DATE] [ANONYMIZED] rather than a [DATE] lunchtime as it would be less busy and that I wouldn't be clogging up the tills.I found this rich coming from someone who has clearly proved over [DATE] that they have not dealt with queue management at all properly after the feedback I provided in my email of [DATE]. He was instead blaming me as a customer for creating long queues when in fact it's his bad management that was causing it. How [ANONYMIZED] customer can be held responsible for causing long queues is beyond me as "clogging up" [ANONYMIZED] self service till would not cause this. Bad queue management might be a more realistic reason for the stores shortfalls rather than blaming [ANONYMIZED] customer. It was not only this that surprised and irritated me, but the terminology the store manager used to label me as "odd" and a "wrong un". I find this very primitive and wholly unacceptable as it only helped to inflame the situation. Not even [DATE] would this have been acceptable. All in all, it was a very poor showing from Asda and an even more poor showing from the store manager trying to tell me when I can and can't do my shopping in store and the offensive and insulting terminology used to convey his message which borders on being a hate crime. It's the type of behaviour you'd expect from someone who is drunk and disorderly, out on a [DATE] [ANONYMIZED] to engage in [LOCATION] behaviour, but not a store manager. I did explain to him that if he'd have managed the queues better, then there wouldn't have been a problem in the [ANONYMIZED] place, but he wasn't willing to accept this feedback and then just told me to go away.I've been a customer of Asda for a long time and have made many online orders, especially over [DATE] (as you can probably check from my email address), but this experience has left me seething with anger at the vulgarity & bluntness shown by the store manager whom I can only describe as not being a fit and proper person at all, and certainly shouldn't be a store manager if addressing customers in such a repulsive way.[PERSON] be leaving reviews on trustpilot and Google about this store, and will also pass this experience on to the [PERSON]? consumer group. I would like to know from you why this store manager was so abrasive in their dealings with me [DATE] and and explanation of the whole episode as to why he found it necessary to use such offensive language and expect some form of redress for the anger this has caused.People like that shouldn't be working in a customer facing role full stop!I look forward to your prompt response.

title: I will no longer be shopping at Asda
body: I will no longer be shopping at Asda. I am disabled and have agoraphobia. Which is why I get food delivery service. The no bag policy on deliveries is silly. I have to stand at the door taking all my products out the baskets and put them on my floor. Sometimes I have to tip all my items out onto the floor because I am agoraphobic I do not like to be stood with my door open for long. This makes it awfully chaotic for me as I am also disabled, then I have to pick all my items up off the floor to take them to the kitchen. It created so much stress and anxiety for me each time I got a shop. If you want to cut down on plastics. Use paper bags!!!!! People get food deliveries for a reason. I have now switched supermarkets so I don't have to deal with all that pain and anxiety anymore.It's really unfair to those with mental health and disibilities and something needs to change. Just use paper bags. Problem solved.Not to mention the substitutes are always nothing remotely similar to what I wanted to order. Stock is always low. Very poor service from Asda.Deliveries are always late and always went to the wrong address and it just caused so much stress every time. Now switched to morrisons. Bye Asda. Hope you resolve these issues for other poor souls who have to struggle like I did with the delivery service.

title: [PERSON] on my spuds!
body: Asda, like many other companies now have AI complaints and enquiry systems, the net result is that, not only can you not talk to a human, but you can't write to a human etc. As a result of trawling their website and google, I have found the most effective way of communicating my concerns is to do it on here, if Asda are not prepared to listen to their customers then perhaps it's best to alert their customers to problems. So what am I concerned about?Home delivery! [DATE] was the [ANONYMIZED] occasion in [DATE] that I have had to reject groceries because they have been contaminated with cleaning products. I assume the packing is done by humans, and I further assume that there is a lack of common sense when it comes to packing items which are to be transported in a crate, within a van.   Why in the world would anyone with a degree of common sense be placing heavy items on top of items which are fragile or may leak? come to that, why would Asda adopt a process of packing items which may be harmful if consumed in with food items.  For very good reasons, supermarkets generally segregate 'toxic' items such as soaps, bleaches, cleaning products from food items when displaying them for sale. Why then would someone packing those items for delivery choose to store them underneath or along side food items. Even if the food item is contained within packaging, bleaches with cause rust to tins and possible eat through plastics or card. The solution of course is simple. Any of these type of products should be packed into separate spill proof containers and placed in the vehicle separate from food items and at a low level. Though there may be an initial cost in obtaining bespoke containers for this task, I believe it would save Asda huge sums of money in disregarded products and time from the drivers point of view.

title: Appalling
body: Ref: [ANONYMIZED]-006871Windmill shopping centre /Smethwick Date of incident [DATE] at 16.09pm I visited your store [DATE]  to do my [DATE] shopping on the way out I noticed security guards and a few staff members having an altercation . I assume she stole something or they thought she did not sure which one as I wasn’t listening to the conversation The woman was visibly upset and from my opinion she was vulnerable as she appeared to be either inebriated or in drugs . I cannot tell you what happened or what she said but they searched her and she left the building . I did notice that it wasn’t just security that was dealing with this lady in her space but staff too which to me didn’t seem right and was escalating the situation when it could of been handled in a more professional manner . Customers shouldn’t have to witness a person being hanged up in when security are paid to do that .I proceeded to notice this fracas and walked out to go to my car I was just outside the door leaving the store and I noticed the woman who had been in the store previously and she had slipped and fallen on the ground and pulled herself up while her partner was berating her . To my shock the sales person who I now know as DANIEL proceeded to barge out of the shop as this woman got to her feet and shouted don’t come back you tramp and other obscenities in  front of all the customers outside.You can imagine how shocked I was and I was walking quite near this woman . He seemed unhinged and has anger issues I turned around and went back to speak to them as I was in shock . I told DANIEL that his attitude was appalling and unprofessional to be shouting at a customer in front of other customers. He said to me that she wasn’t a customer and she was being racist another member of staff who was beside him said in a loud vice she called me racist names . Now I am a women of colour myself and what I was hearing was very disturbing . The  staff had basically ganged up on this vulnerable woman and thought it was their right to act like hoodlums because they were offended I am in no way condoning this vulnerable woman’s behaviour at all I am more concerned about the unprofessional way it was handled there  is no excuse . Customers shouldn’t have to listen to Asda staff going on a tirade of abuse to a member of the public . Security are there for a reason and that it what they get paid fir to handle situations like this I do not expect staff to think it is okay to  follow a member of the public out of the store and go in on a tirade of abuse as it certainly doesn’t make customers want to come back . They should have recognised she was vulnerable and acted with a degree of professionalism they did not do that hanging up on a woman security guards and staff is not a good look Everyone who visits your store is a person a human being and should be treated in an empathic manner. This person did not do this and thought he was allowed to treat this person in an inhumane way and their would be no accountability . How I know this is when I told him I was going to make a complaint he said I don’t care and treated me with the same disdain as he did that vulnerable woman and walked off didn’t want to hear it  . I would also like to mention the young woman who thought there was nothing wrong with his response and thought because she felt offended it was okay what  [PERSON] did . I sincerely hope you investigate and take this seriously as behaviour  like this by your staff member is wrong . And the situation could have been handled in a more respectful empathic and humane way . Miss [PERSON]

Eventually the [ANONYMIZED] call handler assured me however that within a further [DATE] I would receive a response (it being [DATE] to resolve such an issue). The whole process on that particular day probably took over an hour.It’s now over [DATE] and no response whatsoever. I’ve been an Asda customer now for over [DATE] but when we've needed to speak with customer services they really don’t seem to care at all. I don’t really get how they think it’s acceptable for a) this issue in the [ANONYMIZED] place (an unknown chemical all over an entire shop which had spilled to where my [DATE] children eat); b) such poor customer service, probably the worst I’ve encountered; c) no continuity of anyone dealing with anything, even so much as making [ANONYMIZED] outbound call to us; d) not complying with their own timescales. Had there been any degree of acknowledgement/proactivity it would have been really easy to sort - although it’s so strange for a chemical to be all over a grocery shop and even further that it has caused damage to my property, these things may happen from time to time. It hadn’t been intentional. What is worst for me is the fact they simply do not care, and their own complaints service/customer service is ill-equipped, convoluted and needlessly repetitive. title: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF A BAD SITUATION
body: During the so-called 'cost of living crisis' Asda have used this recession as the perfect excuse to hike up their prices. I was talking to a manager, who rambled on about Asda struggling like everyone, but he laid the blame predominantly on..."The fuel prices for food deliveries is just one main reason for the hiking. If you want the privilage of shopping here, then the store price increases has to pay for that fuel increase" He was rather smug in telling me this, but he was soon shot down when I said "Okay, well it cuts both ways. It also costs me and everyone else who shops in your store, more in petrol to get here, to GIVE YOU our CUSTOM. Without our custom, Asda would be finished. So seeing as we're footing your fuel bill, then shouldn't Asda be footing their customer's fuel bill too? After all, Asda benefits from the PRIVELAGE of our custom, far more than we benefit from Asda, given we could go elsewhere!" He had nothing to say to that.Deslite them struggling, the store has recently been totally refitted with new fridges. To my understanding, the [ANONYMIZED] time in [DATE] since its been open. I wonder where the money came from for that, seeing as they're apparently "struggling" I've been shopping in Tesco as a result of this, where there is a far lesser price hiking. Some items are [DATE] cheaper than Asda, and there's a lot of 'Club Card' offers too. I'm definitely finished with Asda and their extortion.

body: So we went to asda at the [ANONYMIZED] center [DATE] with a £[ANONYMIZED] off voucher when we spend £[ANONYMIZED] or more it's been a little while since we last shopped at asda but it will certainly be our last visit after the disgusting service we encountered, firstly the tills were under staffed causing huge queues down the aisles we purchased £[ANONYMIZED] of groceries and redeemed our voucher at the till, but on examination of our receipt on our way out we found the discount hadn't been applied so we called into the customer service desk to have this rectified,  after a wait of [ANONYMIZED] here told to contact head office ,when we finally got through to  them  the customer services lady said they didn't have the technology to carry out a refund but we could use the voucher again before the [ANONYMIZED] Dec when I complained that we had just bought our [DATE] shop and spent £[ANONYMIZED] with them her answer was for us to return all of our groceries for a refund, well I was cobsmacked if this is what our customer service has come to,  needless to say it will be a long time before we go anywhere near a asda store.

title: Disgraceful
body: I regularly shop at Asda, Boldon. Called in [DATE] to purchase a [DATE] tree, at a cost of £[ANONYMIZED]. As part of the Asda rewards app, I had a voucher for £[ANONYMIZED] off when “spending £[ANONYMIZED] or more on [DATE] lights, trees and decorations”. On scanning the tree, the discount was initially applied, but when I went to pay, the £[ANONYMIZED] discount had been removed. I queried this with a member of staff who couldn’t explain why the discount had not been applied. [ANONYMIZED] other members of staff attempted to assist but again could offer no explanation as to why the discount had not been applied. They called for further assistance. A small, bespectacled man, wearing a [DATE] jumper, possibly a manager? appeared. He was very dismissive, asking if I had read the terms and conditions of the voucher, which I indeed had, before attempting to make my purchase. He then stated that the £[ANONYMIZED] discount on [DATE] tree’s applied only to the £[ANONYMIZED] artificial tree on sale! I asked him, where in the terms and conditions this was stipulated and he was unable to answer this, even after spending over [ANONYMIZED], scrolling through the t&c on the app. He then stated although it was not written anywhere, it was “up to the manager’s discretion”!! Excuse me!! Surely this amounts to false advertising or misrepresentation? It was apparent to me that this manager? was simply making it up as he was going along! Absolutely disgraceful. Shame on you Asda.

title: Asda home delivery is just THE worst
body: Asda home delivery is just THE worst. Out of a £[ANONYMIZED] shop [ANONYMIZED] of my shopping was delivered, just the cupboard items. We thought the driver was going back to the van to get the rest of our shopping. But he never came back. [ANONYMIZED] x chicken, [ANONYMIZED] x mince beef, all the salad and fresh pasta salad for work lunch, cheese, everything fresh basically and everything I need to cook a meal. I spoke to customer service straight away who were no help. Eventually I was transferred, without being told, to another person who eventually called the Chelmsley Wood Asda Store and told me he spoke to the manager. I made it clear without the meat and fresh items I was unable to cook dinner and as this was over a weeks worth of shopping we would be with out food and I didn’t want a refund just the shopping I had ordered, even offered to go and collect it. But alas, these appears impossible when they don’t deliver your shopping!!  I was told the manager said he would call me as soon as the driver was back. This was [ANONYMIZED]. But nothing, I ended up having to order food on my credit card for the family to eat as it was so late. [ANONYMIZED] I have followed the instructions, marked all the items in the app not delivered as missing, and requested a refund. I then got an email to say the refund has been rejected which meant [ANONYMIZED] on the phone and still no food. I’ve been told as she has the list of missing items a refund will be put through and I will hear from the payment team in [ANONYMIZED]. The refund then still needs to be issued. I’m left in the mean time with no food to feed my family and no refund to be able to do any more shopping. To leave a family like this is disgusting. The staff don’t care, customer services are not bothered and either transfer you to someone else or transfer you to a line that just rings out then finally says “there is nobody to take you call” and then cut you off, so you have to call again and go through the whole thing again with someone else. The manager of the store doesn’t care and doesn’t even bother calling back when promised to do so, so I’m now left with no meat, or fresh food which included lunch box stuff for my kids and husband. Absolutely disgusting, I am gutted I have gift vouchers left via a hamper company that I thought would help over [DATE] period as I’m forced to have to use them at Asda again when in reality I would rather go to a supermarket that cares about its customers and doesn’t steal food from them and then withhold customers money preventing them buying replacements. Will not be saving for Asda vouchers ever again, what a waste of money, I aste of time and a whole heap of stress trying to get it all sorted.

title: Horrific home delivery - look elsewhere!
body: This is a review for [ANONYMIZED].I have been using Asda for deliveries for [DATE] now, and have noticed a huge reduction in standards over [DATE]. We probably spend [ANONYMIZED] a week there. The reviews you read on here are an accurate view of what it it like to use Asdas online delivery, so if you're also having issues and have come here to review, I suggest you vote with your feet and find another provider.[ANONYMIZED], their stocking is horrific. I appreciate that stock is only live at the time of your shop, and things can change depending on how busy the store is, but we are getting an increasing number of substitutes each week - none of which make sense. We order boneless chicken thighs [DATE], and these have never been fulfilled and are always swapped for boned thighs or even wings?? I'm starting to doubt they even sell them. Every substitute they give us lower value and quality than the original item.I have never ordered a bottle of spirits or champagne that hasn't had the security tag left on. I just get told "take it in store", totally negating the point of home delivery. Their meat is so low in quality now, I often wonder where they're sourcing it from. Same goes for their fruit and veg. Often out of next, or dated [DATE].The customer service isn't too bad on [ANONYMIZED], although I'm still waiting for a response to an issue they were made aware of [DATE]. Their call centre is outsourced, often difficult to understand and always reading from a script.The app is glitchy, payments often don't go through. All my refunds are refused, even for out of date food, missing items, etc. We have our [DATE] slot booked with Asda, but I think we'll opt for an actual supermarket shop, as I simply don't trust them to provide any of the items we need. Not to mention, they've had [DATE] items "coming soon" on their app since [DATE], but nobody can actually tell me when they'll be available?Their prices have increased enormously over [DATE]. I know everybody has, but Asda really seem to be going over and above what the average increases are. I wouldn't kind if their service had improved, but it's shockingly bad.We've never had an issue with the delivery drivers - they are always lovely, on time and very friendly. Pay the extra and go to a more reliable supermarket. Tesco, [PERSON], [PERSON], they're all a step up from what Asda has become. It's such a shame, as we rarely had issues in [DATE] we've been using them [DATE].
